Okay. Scott, as you would expect, I'm not going to comment about products that we may or may not announce in the future. But to answer indirectly your question, we try to catch market transitions. And within the network becoming the platform, as you articulated and set me up for the question, so I'll try not to blow the answer, it's completely transparent where the movie you're watching is on your – or the music you are listening to, Ned, like the CES announcement is on the individual device, if it's on the set-top, if it's on your PC, if it's in the service provider point of presence or their data centers or the content generation data centers or somewhere out in the world wide web, that is tailor-made for routing Cisco and networking.

And so as you think about that occurring, we are going to move intelligence throughout every element of the network, security throughout every element of the network, storage into most of the elements, application capability into most of them. So you will see us be aggressive from the home through the data center. And we don't focus on standalone markets. We don't do standalone products. Ned won't do a standalone device. We won't do a standalone – similar mentality within the data center. It's how it architecturally comes together.

So if you look at what we did with the Nexus 5000 announcement and how we're going to evolve, it really speaks to a next generation of data centers in how we go after this market, a next generation series of partners, et cetera. And all the way down to the same concept, Ned, was in the consumer space, and I'm going to take this opportunity for you just to kind of weave these two together about interoperability of any device, any content in the home and what we're doing architectural-wise and maybe use the new product announcements you just did that were extremely well received at Consumer Electronics Show. I'll brag on Ned and then give him the ball.

Many people thought that we did Linksys through an acquisition and then Scientific Atlanta with set-top boxes, but weren't sure we could really play in the consumer market. In this Consumer Electronics Show here of just a couple weeks ago, we received more press than any other player except Microsoft in number of stories written, et cetera. We won a number of the consumer new product announcements and directions. But again, these are not standalone devices. It's how we share any device to any content, data, voice, video, wire to wireless. So Ned?

Great, John. Thanks very much. So as you point out, I think what we're seeing very simply, and this is driven as we look at all of our strategies, John, by the customer – in this case the consumer – that the consumer demand is shifting from point products and point applications to what we refer to as the media enabled home, the ability to connect all of their devices together and be able to share and experience their content and media across all of those devices equally, and the network is exceptionally well positioned to be able to be the platform to enable that to happen.

So when you look at the announcements we made at CES, specifically our media hub platform, which opens up media for the first time to be shared seamlessly across devices connected to the network, both within the home and outside the home, as well as our partnership around connected devices and opening up the technology on the network to enable consumer electronics companies to connect – enable their consumers to connect easily and provision easily to the network, we have the opportunity to really drive that network platform, and it really is an architectural approach, as we've always talked about.

What's exciting here, Scott, is that it's much what we've seen before. When the network becomes a platform, it opens up a whole new set of applications, business models, directions. And what we've seen in the past is it makes the market bigger for all of us. I think there's some peers who will tend to focus on the device level and say this is my territory and you're in my territory. We've never done that versus our peers, and we're not going to do it forward. We think the pie will get dramatically bigger. We'd like a smaller piece of the pie, but we think it's going to be a lot bigger revenue-wise than what you would get. And I think that comes with us coming out of the Internet background.

Now, because we had so much material to cover today and we wanted to be very specific on the detail, we're going to run a couple of minutes longer than normal. You won't see our calls go that long normally, but we wanted to – and Nikos, I think you worded it best – do the importance of getting the data right and people do not misunderstand what we're doing or what we're doing, we went a little bit longer and I apologize for that. So rather than stop at this time, Blair, I'd like to take a couple more questions.
Great, great. So let's go ahead and take another question, please.
Thank you. Our next questions will be from Jason Ader of William Blair. Your line is open.

Yes, thank you. John, I wanted to ask you about your approach to acquisitions in this environment. You said I think in the past, or at least I think I've heard you've said that you wished you were more aggressive during the last downturn. And given the transition that's going on in data centers especially and in light of potential for some repatriation legislation as part of the stimulus package, I was wondering, would your approach to acquisitions be different this time around?

Well, breaking the question into a couple pieces; first is the exciting part about today's market is just about everybody's for sale. And the second most exciting part is the prices are pretty reasonable, Ned, even by your standard of toughness. And our ideal target has not changed: 100 engineers, a product that if you just come to market that's hot or about to come to market, and I think you will see us active in all segments of the market. In fact, if I were betting, it would not surprise me to see us move on the consumer side before you see us even move on some of the other areas.

In terms of your indirect question, John, why haven't you moved? Well, the answer's real simple. The markets continue to go down. So by not moving up to this point in time, it's probably been a good decision on our part. Nobody can judge the bottom, and obviously we're not going to attempt to. But our watching the market at this time has served us very, very well in terms of direction. But my ideal target has not changed.

Having said that, if we come out of this economic slowdown without being very aggressive on both on our internal development, which we clearly have painted a picture today we're going to do, our new ideas and new approaches, and acquisitions starting with the consumer because I have signed off on Ned's business plan to move to 3 to 5 billion for his area of responsibility with a chance to get to 10 – and Ned, I'm going to hold you accountable for that – but you will see us active across the board in each category. But I'd say up to now, our hesitation in terms of timing has worked out well, but we don't try to, again, figure out when the bottom will be. We tend more when the market transitions will occur, they clearly are occurring in our opinion over the next six to 12 months. And this is tailor-made for us in terms of the approach.

Unfortunately the repatriation decision was turned down in the Senate last night. That would have been a great chance to see an additional 600 to $750 billion brought back to the U.S. and put into the market, which is almost the size of the stimulus package. But I understand the decision's on the politics side and we'll move on from that. But that probably should not be part of your analysis, Jason, in terms of cash availability for me or other players.
Thank you.
Okay, can we take another question, please?
Thank you. Our next question will be from Jeff Kvaal of Barclays Capital. Your line is open.

Yes, thanks very much. John, I was wondering if you could give us a flavor of if there was a particular customer set that was weaker towards the end of the year into this year. And then why would you – what gives you the confidence to include the January decline year over year as the bottom end of the revenue guidance range for the third quarter?

Okay, very fair question. I'm not trying to dodge it. I just want to think for a second. I think the one that weakened a little bit faster than we expected would have been service provider, Rick. And we saw that in most geographies around the world, even in Japan where the next generation networks are clearly going to occur. They took the foot off the gas pedal for a period of time, didn't hit the brakes, but sure as heck weren't accelerating. Rob, here in the U.S. our big interface customers such as Verizon and AT&T, where we've got great relationships, they slowed a little bit. And candidly, Comcast, Time Warner, and other cable companies did as well.

John, another thing in terms of providers, particularly in the U.S., Rob, is the extraordinary growth leading up to this downturn that we experienced there, comparisons really exacerbate some of the gross changes in the short term.

They do in the short term. I agree, Rick. But I think also your networks are going to get loaded long term. And if you were to say back to the second part of the question, Jeff, is you can't stop putting in storage or servers. You basically can only run those and when they get filled, you've got to add more. The network you can run hotter and you can balance a little bit and live with a little bit of degradation in the process. And so that was probably the one that surprised me a little bit with the speed at which it slowed down.

Having said that, our relationship has never been stronger across most all service providers around the world, and the loads are continuing to increase. You will have a temporary perhaps hesitation in terms of the companies lay off people, but the loads will continue to grow in the network. And so that's probably the one that I say has the potential to come back with the most predictability.

So back to the second part of your question, it's probably the commercial marketplace that I'll watch. That tends to spend – when their business goes up, they spend. They tend not to pay as much attention to the "herd" instinct. The bottom line is if business is good, they spend; and if not, they don't. Other aspects, hot products sell. Ned, we've seen that again even in the tough season in the holidays, the real hot products, high definition TVs, et cetera, did sell well, even in tough times. So I hope that helps, Jeff. I know it's not an ideal answer, but it's a snapshot of what we're seeing.
Thank you.
And John, I think we have time for just one more question.
Okay.
Great, next question, please.
Thank you. Our final question will be from Simon Leopold of Morgan Keegan. Your line is open.

Great, thanks. Maybe we can leave on a more positive note then. You talked about being a bit more optimistic, John, in terms of the recovery maybe late in '09. If you could talk about what a recovery actually might look like in terms of what recovers first for you, clearly you've suggested the U.S. What I'm wondering is routers have been down quite a bit. So do they snap back or do we continue to see more favorable trends from some of the advanced technology? So a little bit more color on what the recovery looks like even if you can't talk about the timing? Thanks.

To the question that you started with, routers tend to tie very closely to loads on networks and tie very closely to what service providers are seeing. So I think while there is a lot in enterprise and some in the commercial marketplace, your question with about router numbers will turn up as network loads continue to grow. That's inevitable; the only question is how quickly does it snap back, to your point. And the second part is how good a job do we do in partnering with service providers to help them monetize those loads, which is a very important issue for them as they go forward.

However, to your second part that you're leading me toward, the advanced technologies look pretty good. And Rob, we were talking about that about areas that we think we could be even more aggressive on. And Ned you and I were talk thing morning about video and architecturally playing more across the board. TelePresence, as an example, will become material a year from now in terms of the volume. It's probably the best way for CEOs really to understand what collaboration and Web 2.0 is about.

Now if you're saying, John, what do you think is going to be the hottest thing we're talking about year from now? It's going to be collaboration and Web 2.0. I mean, you watch those ramp-up numbers, which we saw. That is identical to what happen in '93 – '94 when we were doing – we were the first company really doing a lot of orders over the Internet and doing the majority of our support over the Internet. These numbers are equally as aggressive except they are by month, not by quarter. And for those of you who have been following those numbers with us, you notice they uptick every month that has occurred over the last 12.

So my own view of what's going to be most exciting on this upturn is Web 2.0 technologies changing business models and collaboration. People at first tend to hesitate about jumping into that until they see the payback and productivity. And then they begin to ramp, but that's probably an area that I'm personally am the most excited about looking 12 to 24 months out.

So Simon, I want to thank you for ending on a positive note. Blair, I always tease you about you always saying we'll take one or two more questions and make sure we get one we can end on a positive note with, and Simon saved us and that was very kind. So let me switch it to you.

Okay, great. Thanks, John. As a reminder, Cisco's next quarterly conference call, which will reflect our third quarter fiscal year 2009 results, will be on Wednesday, May 6, 2009, at 1:30 p.m. Pacific Time, 4:30 p.m. Eastern.

Additionally, downloadable Q2 financial statements will be available following this call, including revenue segments by product and geography. Income statements, full GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information, balance sheets, and cash flow statements can be found on our website in the Investor Relations section. And again, just click on the financial section of the website to access those.

Again, I would like to remind you that in light of Regulation Fair Disclosure, Cisco plans to retain its longstanding policy not to comment on its financial guidance during the quarter unless it is done through an explicit public disclosure.
Please call the Investor Relations department with any follow-up questions from this call. And thank you again for your participation and continued support. This concludes our call.
